Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract (Uhlmann, 1500517):

The award will support graduate students and postdoctoral researchers to participate in the Applied Inverse problems 2015 (AIP 2015), be held in Helsinki, Finland, May 25-29, 2015, as well as a summer school held also in Helsinki, May 19-22, 2015.

AIP 2015 is one of a series of AIP Conferences aimed to provide a primary international forum for academic and industrial researchers working on all aspects of inverse problems, such as mathematical modelling, analytic and geometric methods, computational approaches, numerical algorithms etc. It will cover a broad spectrum of the applications of inverse problems, focusing on recent developments in medical imaging, determination of defects in materials homogenization and inverse problems, geometric inverse problems, remote sensing, industrial applications, numerical and regularization methods in inverse problems, and also, invisibility and cloaking. More information of the conference can be found at the website http://aip2015.fips.fi/. The NSF support from this award will allow a financial package for US students and postdocs to participate in the conference and the summer school, and will significantly enhance the ability to recruit an outstanding and diverse group of researchers to work in the area of inverse problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Applied Inverse Problems (AIP) Conference was held in Helsinki, Finland, May 25-29, 2015. The week before there was a summer school also held in Helsinki, May 19-22, 2015. The series of AIP conferences held every two years  aim to provide a primary international forum for academic and industrial researchers working in inverse problems. In these problems the causes for a desired or observed effect are to be determined. They lie at the heart of scientific inquiry and technological development. They have found applications in many fields including medical imaging, geophysics, remote sensing, biology, astrophysics to name just a few.  The enormous increase in computer power and the development of powerful algorithms have made possible to apply inverse problems to more complex real-world problems. Another import aspect ofinverse prolems has been the development of methods to achieve invisibility. This arose in the study of electrical impedance tomography, an important imverse problem. In particular the methop of transformation optics was studied at the conference. 

The NSF support gave the opportunity to junior researchers ro learn about the latest developments in inverse problems, to present their results and establish new collaborations with junior and senior researchers. It will undoubtedly have a significant impact in their careers and therefore in the development of future technologies.
